courseTitle: Transcription and Translation Using DNA/RNA Puzzles

pageData.titleName2: Transcription and Translation Using DNA/RNA Puzzles

pageData.text: DNA contains the genetic code for an organism to live, develop, and reproduce. In this investigation, students use puzzle pieces to demonstrate and model molecular events to help visualize and understand the relationship between DNA, the different types of RNAs, and polypeptide formations. The four modeling exercises incorporated into this investigation are designed to be conducted in sequence.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text:
• Permanent marker
  • Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
  • Ruler (metric)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes 
Activity 1: DNA Structure and Replication – 20 minutes 
Activity 2: RNA Structure and Transcription – 30 minutes 
Activity 3: Translation and Protein Synthesis – 20 minutes 
Activity 4: The Effects of Mutation – 20 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Transcription and Translation Using DNA/RNA Puzzles

text: Identify and compare DNA and RNA molecular structures.
Demonstrate the process of <button class='glossary-text'>DNA replication</button>.
Explain the outcome of <button class='glossary-text'>transcription</button> and model the process.
Describe the process and location of <button class='glossary-text'>translation</button>.
Identify the phase the cell is in during each of these processes.
Determine the effects of a DNA <button class='glossary-text'>mutation</button> on the resulting RNA and protein.

pageData.text: Genetic disorders occur when a <button class='glossary-text'>mutation</button> occurs in a gene. Many of these disorders are inherited, such as sickle-cell or hemophilia. Exposure to chemicals, pollutants, and radiation can also cause genetic mutations that are associated with chronic diseases and cancer. However, mutations are not always bad.

One of the genes involved in maintaining bone density in human beings is called low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 5 (LRP5). Certain mutations impair the function of LRP5 and are associated with osteoporosis (low bone density), but a different kind of mutation in LRP5 can increase its function and result in higher levels of bone density. This mutation was discovered after a young person was in a terrible car accident but walked away from it. After the crash, researchers studied the family and discovered that no one in the family had ever broken a bone and had much higher-than-average bone density. The only negative side effect appears to be that some of the family members with the mutation have boney growths in the roof of their mouths1. Researchers are currently working on gene therapies that may enhance the function of LRP5 and prevent osteoporosis.1Boyden, L. M., Mao, J., Belsky, J., Mitzner, L., Farhi, A., Mitnick, M. A., Wu, D., Insogna, K., & Lifton, R. P. (2002). High bone density due to a mutation in LDL-receptor-related protein 5. The New England journal of medicine, 346(20), 1513–1521. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa013444

pageData.altText: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.
pageData.desc: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.

pageData.text: In 1953, Rosalind Franklin, James Watson, and Francis Crick described the structure of DNA, which facilitated the understanding of its replication process. Today, , RNA , and protein synthesis are considered the central dogma of molecular biology. Understanding these events is crucial to the comprehension of biological processes on the molecular scale.

pageData.subTitle: DNA: The Genetic Code
pageData.text: are long, chainlike molecules formed by the linkage of smaller units called . Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is a double-stranded helical nucleic acid that contains genetic information and comprises the genes of organisms (Figure 1).

<button class='glossary-text'>DNA nucleosides</button> are composed of a deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base. When one or more inorganic phosphate groups are added, the nucleoside becomes a nucleotide. The four DNA nitrogenous bases are adenine (A), guanine (G), cytosine (C), and thymine (T). <button class='glossary-text'>Base pairs</button> form between specific nucleobases, because each nitrogenous base can form hydrogen bonds with its complement. Adenine binds with thymine via two hydrogen bonds, and guanine binds with cytosine via three hydrogen bonds. In the DNA double-stranded helix, complementary bases are brought together because portions of the molecules have opposite charges.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

pageData.text: Understanding the naming of the carbons within the sugar molecule is essential to understanding <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acid</button> formation and direction. Deoxyribose is a five-carbon sugar. The sequential designations 1′ (pronounced “one prime”) through 5′ (pronounced “five prime”) identify the position of each carbon atom in the sugar molecule, as shown in Figure 2. In this image, the individual carbon atoms are not drawn—they exist at the line intersections.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.

pageData.text: Within individual <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button>, the phosphate group is bound to the 5′ carbon of the sugar molecule and the nitrogenous base is bound to the 1′ carbon of the sugar molecule. Covalent bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 3′ carbon of the sugar molecule of another nucleotide form the phosphate-sugar backbone of a nucleic acid strand. The two ends of any nucleic acid strand are referred to as the 5′ end and the 3′ end. The 5′ end contains the nucleotide with the phosphate attached to the 5′ carbon of the sugar molecule. The 3′ end is characterized by the  nucleotide having the 3′ carbon of its sugar molecule not attached to a phosphate group.

pageData.question: Which of the following bases are most likely to pair together?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In DNA, the nucleotide bases follow the base-pairing rules, adenine (A) and thymine (T) always pair together with two hydrogen bonds, and guanine (G) and cytosine (C) always pair together with three hydrogen bonds.

pageData.question: What shape does the DNA double helix resemble?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, resembling a twisted ladder.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

img.alt: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

img.alt: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

pageData.subTitle: RNA: The Code Transcribed
pageData.text: While DNA is an organism’s genetic code, ribonucleic acids (RNAs) are the vehicles by which the genetic code is translated into the proteins that perform life’s functions. Like DNA , each RNA nucleotide contains an inorganic phosphate group, a sugar, and a nitrogenous base. In contrast to DNA, the RNA sugar is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine is replaced by uracil (U), which, like thymine, complements adenine. Like DNA molecules, RNA nucleotides bind together to form long strands, and the order of the nucleotides in the RNA sequence is determined by the order of the nucleotides in the parent DNA sequence. In the nucleus, a process called occurs when the DNA double helix unwinds and enzymes in the cell match the complementary RNA bases to the DNA bases in a single DNA strand.

pageData.subTitle: The Transcription Process
pageData.text: : Transcription begins when an enzyme called RNA polymerase binds to DNA at a site with a specific DNA sequence. This site is called the promoter. In eukaryotic cells, other molecules called transcription factors also play a role in initiating the process of RNA synthesis. After the RNA polymerase binds to the DNA, the double helix unwinds, and the two strands separate.

: The enzyme RNA polymerase travels along one of the DNA strands, the template strand, in the 3′ to 5′ direction. As it travels, it reads the DNA sequence and builds a complementary RNA strand, which is generated in the 5′ to 3′ direction (Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

pageData.text: : The RNA polymerase eventually falls off, the two DNA strands bind again, and a complementary single-stranded RNA sequence is free within the nucleus.

pageData.subTitle: Types of RNA
pageData.text: The three major types of RNA that are generated by <button class='glossary-text'>transcription</button> are <button class='glossary-text'>messenger</button> (mRNA), <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomal</button> (rRNA), and <button class='glossary-text'>transfer</button> (tRNA).

text: Messenger RNA provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on the DNA sequence. The code is divided into three-<button class='glossary-text'>nucleotide</button> sequences called <button class='glossary-text'>codons</button> that correspond to a specific amino acid. In eukaryotic cells, several modifications must be made to mRNA to prepare the molecule for <button class='glossary-text'>translation</button>, which is where proteins are synthesized. A cap, which protects the mRNA from enzymatic degradation, is added to the 5′ end, and a poly-A tail, which also protects the mRNA and aids in transport out of the nucleus, is added to the 3′ end. The length of the poly-A tail determines the number of times that the mRNA can be translated and therefore regulates the number of proteins made from the mRNA. Additionally, noncoding regions called <button class='glossary-text'>introns</button> need to be removed from the mRNA molecule before protein synthesis occurs. After all of these modifications are made, the mRNA is ready to be transported from the nucleus into the cytoplasm for translation.

Ribosomal RNA combines with proteins to form complexes called <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button>, which function as the workplaces of protein synthesis. Eukaryotic ribosomes have two subunits. The smaller subunit is referred to as the 40S subunit, which binds mRNA. The larger subunit is called the 60S subunit, which binds the tRNA and amino acids. Each ribosome also has two binding sites, the aminoacyl site (A site) and the peptidyl site (P site), which bind tRNA during protein synthesis.

Transfer RNA molecules serve as carrier molecules in the cytoplasm and facilitate the addition of amino acids to amino acid chains during translation. Transfer RNA is located throughout the cytoplasm, where it reacts with activated amino acids. Activation of the tRNA occurs when an enzyme called aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase brings a free-floating amino acid to the A site of a tRNA molecule, and with energy input from the “energy molecule” adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the amino acid binds to the tRNA at the P site. Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases recognize specific amino acids and specific tRNA molecules; for example, glycine is bound only to glycine-specific tRNA molecules. If a single amino acid is not a match for the specific tRNA, binding does not occur. Several amino acids are linked together in this way, forming a polypeptide chain, which is the most basic form of a protein. Transfer RNA interacts directly with the ribosome to transfer the mRNA-designated amino acids to the assembly of the amino acid chain. The tRNA folds in such a way that its three-nucleotide sequence, called an , can bind with the complementary mRNA codon. The 3′ end of the tRNA sequence contains the amino acid binding site.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the stages of transcription?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Transcription goes through the stages of initiation (RNA polymerase binds to the DNA), elongation (RNA polymerase reads and DNA and synthesis an RNA sequence), and termination (RNA polymerase releases the DNA and the new RNA molecule is complete).

pageData.question: What is one way that DNA is different from RNA?

options.text: DNA has thymine and RNA has uracil.
DNA has ribose and RNA has deoxyribose.
DNA has more enzymes than RNA.
DNA has adenine-thymine base pairing and RNA has adenine-adenine base pairing.
DNA is synthesized on the leading strand and RNA is synthesized on the lagging strand.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA has the nucleotide thymine (T), which is not found in RNA. RNA has the nucleotide uracil (U), which is not found in DNA.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

pageData.subTitle:
Protein Synthesis: The Code Translated
The Translation Process
pageData.text: : During initiation, the small ribosomal subunit binds to and the initiator , which is bound to the amino acid methionine. This complex moves along the mRNA strand until it recognizes the amino acid methionine. This is the start of the sequence. After the initiator tRNA binds to the complementary mRNA sequence at the tRNA P site, several initiation factors help the large ribosomal subunit attach to the complex. The initial methionine amino acid is located on one end of the polypeptide, called the nitrogen terminus (N-terminus). The opposite end of the polypeptide is called the carbon terminus (C-terminus).

: The large ribosomal subunit catalyzes a peptide bond between two amino acids. The then moves the tRNA from the A site to the P site. The former P site tRNA is released from the ribosome without its amino acid. The ribosome then moves the mRNA so that a new rests in the A site. A new tRNA is loaded such that its anticodon matches the next mRNA codon.

: Translation is terminated when the mRNA stop codon moves into the ribosomal A site. A protein called a release factor binds in the place of tRNA, breaking the bond between the tRNA and the newly formed polypeptide. Finally, the ribosomal subunits separate, and the polypeptide is released into the cytoplasm.

: Because DNA is the ultimate repository for the instructions for building most cellular machinery and communication molecules, it is vital that every cell contain a complete copy of all the instructions. Without a mechanism for copying the DNA, cells would have to split the instructions with every cell division, rendering them unable to complete necessary functions. In DNA replication, each strand of the DNA is copied creating two new strands.

During the growth phase (G1 phase) of the cell cycle, parts of the DNA being transcribed into RNA are available to enzymes but regions not being transcribed are tightly wound on proteins called , which bundle and organize the DNA into nucleosomes. Once the cell enters the synthesis phase (S phase), transcription stops and DNA is unwound from the histones at particular regions of the genome called the origins of replication. A protein called DNA helicase begins “unzipping” the DNA, breaking the hydrogen bonds that hold the DNA strands together. After that, a complex of enzymes, including DNA polymerase, begin replicating the DNA, adding free to complement the existing strands.

DNA polymerase, like RNA polymerase, can only add new nucleotides to the 3′ carbon. This means that only one strand, termed the , can be replicated continuously. The other strand, the , has to be completed in short stretches called Okazaki fragments that are later connected together.

When replication is complete, each new, identical DNA strand is made up of one strand of the original DNA molecule and one newly synthesized strand. This means that DNA replication is semiconservative.

pageData.subTitle: Mutations
pageData.text: With advancements in biotechnology, scientists now rely on DNA similarities to determine relationships between groups of organisms. Species that have similar DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from a common ancestor.

Organisms that are more distantly related have, over time, accumulated more differences in their DNA sequences. The difference between DNA sequences, both within a species and across species, is called genetic variation. The mechanism of variation is , a change in DNA sequence. Harmful mutations that hinder an organism’s fitness (its ability to survive and reproduce) are less likely to be passed on to the next generation.

Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected for by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including , , and . A is a change in a that affects a single . Point substitutions can sometimes lead to having one amino acid replaced with another, which can lead to a nonfunctional protein or a protein with completely different characteristics. As an example, when a DNA sequence has ACG, this will translate to a cystine amino acid. Should a point mutation change this sequence to ACT, this now stands for a stop , and protein synthesis will stop after this codon, leading to an incomplete and nonfunctional protein. Insertion occurs when nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence. Deletion occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence. A occurs when nucleotides are inserted or deleted in numbers that are not multiples of three.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Examples of mutations in DNA. Three examples are categorized as point mutations. The first point mutation is labeled silent: it has no effect on the protein sequence. This mutation is an adenine changed to a thymine but the resulting amino acid remains valine. The second point mutation is labeled missense: it results in an amino acid substitution. This mutation is an adenine changed to a cytosine, and the resulting amino acid changed from proline to threonine. The third point mutation is labeled nonsense: it substitutes a stop codon for an amino acid. This mutation is a cytosine changed to a guanine, and the resulting amino acid changed from tyrosine to stop. A fourth example is categorized as a frameshift mutation. Insertions or deletions of nucleotides may result in a shift in the reading frame or insertion of a stop codon. This mutation is a thymine and adjacent adenine are deleted, and the resulting amino acid remains the same but subsequent amino acids are different from the original.

pageData.text: mutations.png by OpenStax is available under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License at https://openstax.org/books/biology-2e/pages/14-6-dna-repair?query=mutations&target=%7B%22index%22%3A0%2C%22type%22%3A%22search%22%7D#fs-id1310247

pageData.question: Which of the following describes a point mutation?

options.text: a nucleotide is replaced with a different nucleotide
two nucleotides are inserted at the end of a DNA sequence
two nucleotides are replaced with two different nucleotides
two nucleotides are deleted from the beginning of a DNA sequence

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A point mutation is a change in a single nucleotide in a nucleic acid sequence, whether the change be a substitution, insertion, or deletion.

pageData.question: Which of the following mutations is/are most likely to cause a shift in the reading frame during translation?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A frameshift mutation refers to the insertion or deletion of nucleotide bases in numbers that are not multiples of three.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected for by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including substitutions, insertions, and deletions. A point mutation is a change in a nucleic acid that affects a single nucleotide. Point substitutions can sometimes lead to having one amino acid replaced with another, which can lead to a nonfunctional protein or a protein with completely different characteristics. As an example, when a DNA sequence has ACG, this will translate to a cystine amino acid, resulting in a stop codon, leading to an incomplete and nonfunctional protein. Insertion occurs when nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence. Deletion occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence. A frameshift mutation occurs when nucleotides are inserted or deleted in numbers that are not multiples of three.

img.alt: Figure 4: Examples of mutations in DNA. Three examples are categorized as point mutations. The first point mutation is labeled silent: it has no effect on the protein sequence. This mutation is an adenine changed to a thymine but the resulting amino acid remains valine. The second point mutation is labeled missense: it results in an amino acid substitution. This mutation is an adenine changed to a cytosine, and the resulting amino acid changed from proline to threonine. The third point mutation is labeled nonsense: it substitutes a stop codon for an amino acid. This mutation is a cytosine changed to a guanine, and the resulting amino acid changed from tyrosine to stop. A fourth example is categorized as a frameshift mutation. Insertions or deletions of nucleotides may result in a shift in the reading frame or insertion of a stop codon. This mutation is a thymine and adjacent adenine are deleted, and the resulting amino acid remains the same but subsequent amino acids are different from the original.

Point substitutions can sometimes lead to having one amino acid replaced with another, which can lead to a nonfunctional protein or a protein with completely different characteristics. As an example, when a DNA sequence has ACG, this will translate to a cystine amino acid, resulting in a stop codon, leading to an incomplete and nonfunctional protein. Insertion occurs when nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence. Deletion occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence. A frameshift mutation occurs when nucleotides are inserted or deleted in numbers that are not multiples of three.

This mutation is an adenine changed to a thymine but the resulting amino acid remains valine. The second point mutation is labeled missense: it results in an amino acid substitution. pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, sort and identify the puzzle pieces. In activity 1, label the carbons on a deoxyribose piece. Next, build DNA nucleosides, then DNA nucleotides. Next, build complementary DNA strands and simulate DNA replication. Finally, disassemble the models. In activity 2, build a single strand of DNA. Then, build a complementary RNA strand. Finally, determine the amino acid sequence from the RNA codons. In activity 3, build a single DNA strand and a complementary RNA strand. Then, activate the tRNAs and simulate protein synthesis. In activity 4, for each of 3 different mutations, modify the DNA strand sequence from activity 3, build a complementary RNA strand, and determine the amino acid sequence from the RNA codons.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is not a nitrogenous base found in DNA?
Which of the following statements about the base pairs of DNA is correct?

options.text: Adenine binds to thymine via two hydrogen bonds.
Guanine binds to cytosine via two hydrogen bonds.
Adenine binds to guanine via three hydrogen bonds.
Guanine binds to thymine via three hydrogen bonds.
Adenine binds to cytosine via two hydrogen bonds.

assestmentData.question: Which of these is the enzyme responsible for transcription?
Which of the following does NOT take place between transcription and translation?

options.text: a cap is added to the 5’ end of the mRNA
a poly-A tail is added to the 3’ end of the mRNA
mRNA is transported to the cytoplasm

assestmentData.question: Which of these is the sugar in an RNA nucleotide?
Which sequence below lists the steps of transcription in the correct order?
Which of these is the type of RNA that provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on the DNA sequence?
In which phase of the cell cycle does DNA replication occur?
Which of the following best describes a daughter DNA molecule produced by DNA replication?

options.text: It consists of one parent strand and one daughter strand.
It consists of two daughter strands identical to the parent strands.
It consists of two strands each made up of parent and daughter sequences.
It consists of a leading strand and multiple lagging strands.
It consists of two daughter strands that differ from the parent strands.

assestmentData.question: What type of RNA serves as an amino acid carrier in the cytoplasm?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Remove all pieces from the bag.
Sort and identify all pieces to ensure that all pieces are present.
In Activity 1, you will use the puzzle pieces to assemble DNA . You will then assemble a double stand or DNA using base-pairing rules and simulate .

Obtain the following pieces:
  • 24 deoxyribose sugars
  • 24 phosphates
  • 4 adenine (A) bases
  • 8 cytosine (C) bases
  • 8 guanine (G) bases
  • 4 thymine (T) bases

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Examine a deoxyribose sugar puzzle piece, which is dark pink. Orient the deoxyribose sugar puzzle piece as in Figure 1. Not all the atoms are printed on the puzzle piece. Each of the points of the pentagon represents a carbon atom, with the exception of the point where the “O” is printed. Starting with the 1′ carbon on the top point of the pentagon, label each point with the appropriate number. You should have 4 carbons labeled. The 5′ carbon is already printed on the piece as part of the CH<sub>2</sub> functional group. Take a photograph of the puzzle piece after the label is complete.

Locate the three knobs on the puzzle piece. These represent potential covalent bonds. The knob at the 5′ carbon represents the binding site for a phosphate group, and the knob at the 1′ carbon represents the binding site for the nitrogenous base.

Build <button class='glossary-text'>DNA nucleosides</button> for all of the nitrogenous bases you have collected. A nucleoside includes a deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base. Nucleosides lack phosphate groups.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Add a phosphate to the 5′ carbon of each nucleoside. This will transform each nucleoside into a . Nucleotides are composed of a nucleoside with one or more phosphate groups. Take a photograph of one of your completed nucleotides.

Connect one A, one T, two Gs, and two Cs in a random sequence by attaching the phosphate group of one nucleotide to the free knob at the 3′ carbon of another nucleotide. The order of nucleotides that you choose represents the DNA sequence.

Using some of the free nucleotides, pair each base in the DNA strand with its complementary nucleotide until you have built a double-stranded DNA chain comprising six . The hydrogen bonds between complementary nucleotides are weaker than the bonds between the nucleotides in individual strands. Notice that the two strands are antiparallel, meaning they run in opposite directions. One strand is described as running in the 5′ to 3′ direction and the other runs in the 3′ to 5′ direction.
Separate the two DNA strands a distance of approximately 30 centimeters. The weak hydrogen bonding between the base pairs allows for this separation.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Use the remaining free nucleotide pieces to rebuild the missing half of each DNA strand, beginning at the 5′ ends of the original strands. Note that the new, complementary DNA strands are synthesized in the 5′ to 3′ direction. Take a photograph of this setup, which represents .
Dismantle the pieces before proceeding to the next activity.
In Activity 2, you will use the puzzle pieces to assemble DNA and RNA . You will then simulate the process of using the nucleotides and determine the amino acids the sequence codes for using a chart.

Obtain the following pieces:
  • 9 ribose sugars (light pink)
  • 18 phosphates
  • 5 cytosine (C) bases
  • 2 thymine (T) bases
  • 9 deoxyribose sugars (dark pink)
  • 4 adenine (A) bases
  • 5 guanine (G) bases
  • 2 uracil (U) bases
Compare the ribose and deoxyribose sugars. Note the difference in structure between the two sugars.

Build the following DNA <button class='glossary-text'>nucleotides</button>: two As, three Cs, two Gs, and two Ts. Use the deoxyribose sugar, and remember to attach the phosphate group to the 5′ carbon.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Assemble the nine DNA nucleotides in any order. The phosphate group of one nucleotide binds with the free knob at the 3′ carbon of the adjacent nucleotide. During <button class='glossary-text'>transcription</button>, the two strands of DNA separate and one of them, named the template strand or antisense strand, is used as a guide to build a complementary RNA strand. In this model, you have prepared only the template strand. Record your sequence from 5′ to 3′. Take a photograph of your sequence from 5′ to 3′, and record this sequence.
Build the following free-floating RNA nucleotides: two As, two Cs, three Gs, and two Us. Remember to use ribose as the component sugar molecule.

Beginning with the 3′ end of the DNA strand, pair each free RNA nucleotide with its DNA complement. Remember that, in RNA, uracil (U) complements adenine (A). RNA polymerase catalyzes this process. Notice that the RNA strand is being synthesized in the 5′ to 3′ direction. Record the sequence of your RNA strand, 5′ to 3′.
Separate the DNA and RNA strands. After RNA is formed, it is released from DNA and moves to other parts of the cell.

Assume the RNA strand that you have made is , and notice that the mRNA contains three . A codon, when translated to a protein, represents one amino acid. Refer to Table 1 to determine what three amino acids are coded for on your mRNA strand. Codons are written in three-letter combinations that are read from the mRNA molecule in the 5′ to 3′ direction. For your sequence, assume that the first three nucleotides represent the first codon. Record the sequence in this model.

pageData.title: Table 1: mRNA Codons for Amino Acids

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will use the puzzle pieces to assemble a DNA sequence and transcribe it into RNA. You will then use the <button class='glossary-text'>tRNA</button> pieces to translate the sequence into a polypeptide strand. You will keep your original DNA sequence for Activity 4.

Use the following puzzle pieces to assemble DNA . Remember, each nucleotide will consist of a base, a sugar, and a phosphate.
  • 2 adenine nucleotides
  • 2 guanine nucleotides
  • 5 cytosine nucleotides
  • thymine nucleotide
Obtain the following additional pieces:
  • binding sheet
  • 2 glycine-specific
  • 2 alanine-specific tRNAs
  • 2 glycine-activating enzymes
  • 2 alanine-activating enzymes
  • 2 glycine amino acids
  • 2 alanine amino acids

Build a DNA strand with the following sequence. Remember that the 3′ carbon in the first nucleotide should not connect to a phosphate group.
5′ GCC ACC TGC 3′

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Build the complementary RNA sequence. Take a photograph, and record the resulting RNA sequence, starting with the 5′ end.
Put your DNA strand aside for Activity 4.
Activate all four tRNA complexes. The piece labeled “Alanine Activating” represents the aminoacyl RNA synthetase enzyme for alanine. Connect the amino acids to their respective activating enzymes.
Connect the enzymes to the matching tRNAs.

Place your <button class='glossary-text'>mRNA</button> sequence onto the ribosome binding sheet. The <button class='glossary-text'>codon</button> of the 5′ end should be above the A site on the 40S ribosome. The rest of the sequence should trail off to the left of the ribosome binding sheet.

Activated amino acids attached to tRNA are free-floating around the ribosome in the cytoplasm. Align the puzzle pieces to test the <button class='glossary-text'>anticodon</button> tRNA site with the mRNA sequence of the first codon above the A site. If the tRNA is not a match, find the one that is. In this model, there are only two types of amino acids, but in reality, there are 20 specific tRNA molecules, each binding different amino acids.

Once the appropriate tRNA is in the A site, shift the mRNA strand and the tRNA complex by sliding the pieces to the right until the tRNA fits in the P site. As the previous tRNA shifts out of the P site, the new amino acid is transferred to the end of the polypeptide chain via a peptide bond.
Find the appropriate tRNA for the next mRNA codon, and place it in the A site.

Once the appropriate tRNA is in the A site, shift the mRNA strand and tRNA complex by sliding the pieces to the right until this tRNA fits in the P site. As the previous tRNA shifts out of the P site, the new amino acid is transferred to the end of the polypeptide chain via a peptide bond.
Once the tRNA exits the P site, it leaves the ribosome. Disconnect the activating enzyme, and then move the tRNA away from the ribosome.
Repeat Steps 7–12 for the last two mRNA codons.
The sequence of amino acids in a protein or polypeptide is listed from the N-terminus to the C-terminus. Record the sequence in this model.
In Activity 4, you will take the DNA sequence from Activity 3 and mutate it. You will then transcribe and translate the mutated strands and observe the changes to the resulting polypeptide chains.

Start with your antisense DNA strand from Activity 3:
5′ GCC ACC TGC 3′

Remove the thymine from the sequence and replace it with a glycine so that the sequence reads:
5′ GCC ACC GGC 3′
This replacement represents a point .

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Build the complementary RNA sequence. Take a photograph, and record the resulting RNA sequence, starting with the 5′ end.

Use <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button> to translate the new <button class='glossary-text'>mRNA</button> molecule into its corresponding amino acid sequence. Record the sequence in this model.

Return your antisense DNA strand to its original sequence:
5′ GCC ACC TGC 3′

Change the final cytosine in your DNA sequence to a thymine
5′ GCC ACC TGT 3′
This also represents a point substitution, but this time, the is in the first position of the rather than the third.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Build the complementary RNA sequence. Take a photograph, and record the resulting RNA sequence, starting with the 5′ end.
Use Table 1 to translate the new mRNA molecule into its corresponding amino acid sequence. Record the sequence in this model.

Return your antisense DNA strand to its original sequence:
5′ GCC ACC TGC 3′

Separate your DNA strand before the thymine. Add a guanine to the strand. This is a point .
5′ GCC ACC GTG C 3′

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Build the complementary RNA sequence. Take a photograph, and record the resulting RNA sequence, starting with the 5′ end.
Use Table 1 to translate the new mRNA molecule into its corresponding amino acid sequence. Record the sequence in this model.
Return all materials to their bags.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Questions
text: What is the sequence of your template DNA strand from 5′ to 3′?
What is the sequence of the complementary RNA strand from 5′ to 3′ that you constructed in Activity 2 step 6?
What are the three amino acids you determined to be encoded by your mRNA in Activity 2 step 8? Did any of the codons specify something other than an amino acid (i.e., a stop codon)? If so, which?

pageData.title: Questions
text: What were the mRNA and amino acid sequences generated in Activity 4 steps 3-4? What was the effect of the mutation on the amino acid sequence?

What were the mRNA and amino acid sequences generated in Activity 4 steps 11-12? What was the effect of the mutation on the amino acid sequence?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.
Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

Figure 4: Examples of mutations in DNA. Three examples are categorized as point mutations. The first point mutation is labeled silent: it has no effect on the protein sequence. This mutation is an adenine changed to a thymine but the resulting amino acid remains valine. The second point mutation is labeled missense: it results in an amino acid substitution. This mutation is an adenine changed to a cytosine, and the resulting amino acid changed from proline to threonine. The third point mutation is labeled nonsense: it substitutes a stop codon for an amino acid. This mutation is a cytosine changed to a guanine, and the resulting amino acid changed from tyrosine to stop. A fourth example is categorized as a frameshift mutation. Insertions or deletions of nucleotides may result in a shift in the reading frame or insertion of a stop codon. This mutation is a thymine and adjacent adenine are deleted, and the resulting amino acid remains the same but subsequent amino acids are different from the original.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, sort and identify the puzzle pieces. In activity 1, label the carbons on a deoxyribose piece. Next, build DNA nucleosides, then DNA nucleotides. Next, build complementary DNA strands and simulate DNA replication. Finally, disassemble the models. In activity 2, build a single strand of DNA. Then, build a complementary RNA strand. Finally, determine the amino acid sequence from the RNA codons. In activity 3, build a single DNA strand and a complementary RNA strand. Then, activate the tRNAs and simulate protein synthesis. In activity 4, for each of 3 different mutations, modify the DNA strand sequence from activity 3, build a complementary RNA strand, and determine the amino acid sequence from the RNA codons.

pageData.content: Table 1. mRNA Codons for Amino Acids
pageData.title: Table 1: mRNA Codons for Amino Acids

data.title: Anticodon
data.content: A three-nucleotide sequence in a tRNA molecule that corresponds to a complementary codon in mRNA

data.title: Base pairs
data.content: Two nitrogen-containing bases (nucleotides) that pair together between strands to form the ladder-like structure of DNA

data.title: Codon
data.content: A three-nucleotide sequence that corresponds to a specific amino acid

data.title: Deletion
data.content: A type of mutation that occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence

data.title: DNA nucleoside
data.content: A unit of DNA composed of deoxyribose sugar and a nitrogenous base; it becomes a nucleotide when an inorganic phosphate base is added

data.title: DNA replication
data.content: The process of duplicating DNA during cell division

data.title: Elongation
data.content: The process of an enzyme reading a DNA sequence and building a complementary strand of RNA during transcription; it is also the process of a ribosome reading an mRNA sequence and building a complementary sequence of amino acids during translation

data.title: Frameshift mutation
data.content: A change in the reading frame of a nucleic acid sequence caused by the insertion or deletion of nucleotides in numbers that are not multiples of three

data.title: Histone
data.content: Any of a group of proteins found in chromatin

data.title: Initiation
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase binding to a site with a specific DNA sequence to start transcription; also the process of a ribosome identifying and binding to the AUG codon of an mRNA strand to start translation

data.title: Insertion
data.content: A mutation in which nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence

data.title: Intron
data.content: A non-coding region of an mRNA sequence

data.title: Lagging strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 3' to 5' direction

data.title: Leading strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 5' to 3' direction

data.title: Messenger RNA (mRNA)
data.content: The RNA molecule that carries protein-coding information from the DNA in the nucleus to ribosomes in the cytoplasm for protein synthesis

data.title: Mutation
data.content: A change in a nucleic acid sequence

data.title: Nucleic acid
data.content: A class of biological macromolecule consisting of long, chainlike molecules made up of nucleotide units

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: The monomer of nucleic acids; it consists of a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Point mutation
data.content: A change to a single nucleotide in a nucleic acid sequence

data.title: Ribosomal RNA (rRNA)
data.content: The RNA molecule that forms part of the ribosome

data.title: Ribosome
data.content: A complex molecular machine that translates mRNA molecules to produce polypeptides (amino acid sequences)

data.title: Substitution
data.content: A mutation in which one nucleotide base is replaced with another nucleotide base

data.title: Termination
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase falling off a DNA molecule at the end of transcription, allowing the two DNA strands reconnect, and the complementary RNA sequence to be free within the nucleus; it is also the process of a ribosome falling off an mRNA strand and the amino acid sequence becoming free within the cell

data.title: Transcription
data.content: The process of synthesizing an mRNA sequence complementary to a DNA sequence for the purpose of synthesizing proteins

data.title: Transfer RNA (tRNA)
data.content: The RNA molecule that carries amino acids to the ribosomes during translation

data.title: Translation
data.content: The process of reading an mRNA sequence to synthesize an amino acid sequence, and ultimately a protein
